intro: Cereus jamacaru subsp. calcirupicola, commonly known as the rock cactus, is a species native to the arid regions of Brazil. It is characterized by its tall, columnar stem that can grow up to several meters in height. The plant produces large, white, night-blooming flowers that are highly fragrant. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires minimal water, making it well adapted to its harsh environment. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
